Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2013 07:40AM belha wrote: I think you were right fredntan, it must have been something from prep. Since I was allowed to shower this morning, I did and made sure to wash the area well (and gently). I ended up falling back asleep for a couple hours (still having some lingering tiredness), and upon waking up again it looks so much better. The itch is gone and the skin is not red and irritated anymore. I will have to make sure to ask the surgeon on my follow up what could have caused it so I know for future refernece. Thanks!
Posts.Title: Post-op rash? belha belha

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2013 01:43PM belha wrote: So, here I am now 5 days post op and my whole upper left side is covered in the rash. It looks like t-shirt lines on my left side. Where the rash ends at my neck and on my upper arm. I have an appt with the surgeon tomorrow, I had called Monday and talked to the nurse as my surgeon was in the OR. So I called back Tuesday and they told me to come in. From what I read on google, and saw pictures it looks like a reaction to Chloraprep (sp?) I'm sure I'll find out more tomorrow. I hope to get some relife, I probably should have just bit the bullet and went to urgent care or the ER over the weekend, but I really didn't want to see a Dr who wasn't my surgeon.
Posts.Title: Post-op rash? belha belha

Posts.Content: belha wrote: I had my lumpectomy yesterday and i noticed an itch last night but thought it was just the tape from the dressing. Well this morning i have a red itchy rash that from about where a t-shirt neckline would lay down in between my breasts and it trails off under my left breast which is where the surgery was. I read online someone had this reaction from the draping? And that would make sense with how my rash is. Any experiences? Im not sure who to call since its Saturday. And its really just more annoying than anything. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2013 11:23AM belha wrote: I actually ended up taking a benedryl because the itch came back. I talked to the nurse and because of where it is and the line it follows, i guess that is the best way to put it, that it is a reaction from the adhesive they used on the draping.

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2013 01:24PM belha wrote: deb, I have to say I can relate to your wedding invite issue. Before I found my lump I was activly seeking a new better job in the field where I recently obtained a Bachleor Degree. Well now I am in the middle of getting the issue taken care of I've had to put job searching off the table, much to my dismay. I just for one, can't lose my medical insurance. (Usually you have a 60-90 wait period at new employment before benefits kick in). Would lose my paid sick time. And, to start a new job and already be like .. Well I need such & such off to get the surgery and then such & such off for follow up appointments.. I just don't think that is fair to a brand new employer. It sucks because its almost like we have to put our lives on hold to deal with these issues. :(

Posts.Title: Freaking out a little bit.. belha Skagitphoenix

Posts.Content: belha wrote: I found a lump in my left breast about 2 months ago, I know I shouldn't have but I waited one menstral cycle to see if it might go away or shrink (thinking it could be a cyst). Well it didn't so I made an appt with my gyno and she felt the lump, and sent me for a diagnostic mammo and ultrasound which I had done on 3/15. The gyno didn't seen worried about my lump. It is oval shaped, very moveable, smooth, and just a little firm. I have no idea how long it has been there, never noticed it before. Recently lost about 20lbs (on purpose, they did a Weight Watchers group at my work) and I did have definate weight loss in my breasts. The lump was noticeable on my mammo, it does have smooth edges all around very clear and defined. They saw it on the ultrasound as well. The radiologist said to me it appears to be a fibroadenoma, but they wanted to send me for an ultrasound needle biopsy to be certain. I went and had that done this afternoon. The radiologist who performed it told me that my lump does have a lot of benign characteristics, but doing this biopsy is pretty much standard procedure just so everyone knows 100% what it is. Now the wait is on until Monday, Tuesday at the latest. It's hard not to think about the what ifs. I am 32 years old, and my husband and I were planning on trying for our first child later this year. I am currently not on any hormonal birth control, but was for a long time before getting married. I was almost in tears in the waiting room today waiting to go in for my procedure. It didn't help they were running almost an hour behind so I had time for all the bad thoughts to run through my mind. I actually had a lump removed from my right breast in 2008. That lump was not moveable, and very hard. Turned out to be scar tissue. That was handled completely different than this one. They did the mammo/ultrasound and then refered me to a surgeon. We monitored the lump for about 4 months, and it didn't change. We decided to remove it under local, so once he got it out he was pretty much able to tell me with 98% certainy he felt it was scar tissue and thats what it turned out to be. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Freaking out a little bit.. belha Skagitphoenix

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2013 01:53PM belha wrote: Heidi, I know what you mean. It's awful having to wait. I am still waiting to here about my CNB results, was hoping for today but it's already 2pm so I am doubtful. I am going crazy. My husband is working midnight shift this week, so when I get home at 5:30pm he is sleeping then gets up and leaves for work at 8:15pm and doesn't get home until after I am gone for work in the morning. It leaves me time for my mind to wonder. Have been just sticking to my daily life routine, and that is keeping me busy until I am laying in bed at night. Sending b9 wishes your way dear, keep us posted!

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2013 04:59PM belha wrote: I am getting a fibroadenoma removed on April 12th. Doing it for peace of mind mostly, (and mine was questioned by pathology). Is yours close to the surface or deeper in? I think it's good you are getting it removed! Just think it will be gone and you won't have to go to those appointments every 6 months! It's an outpaitent procedure, and honestly recovery isn't that bad. I had a lumpectomy in 2009 and it was verrrry easy, done only under local. (Again close to the surface). Good luck to you and let us know how it goes!
Posts.Title: Biopsied Fibroadenoma getting bigger Mommy2Katelynn belha

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2013 05:20PM belha wrote: They can't just do it under local? That's how they are doing mine. Maybe you can ask your surgeon if it's possible, maybe he just assumed you want to be asleep for it because it is still done in the OR and that can be scary.
Posts.Title: Biopsied Fibroadenoma getting bigger Mommy2Katelynn belha

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2013 04:28PM belha wrote: STP127, I am 32 and just went through something similar. My gyn and even the radiologist who did my US and mammo all told me they were 99% sure it was a fibroadenoma but wanted to do a biopsy because of the size (mine was over 2 cm). If you are getting a core needle done it sounds like the mass is solid and not a cyst. The core needle is very easy, they numb you up very well and I didn't feel a thing. My Dr who did this was very nice, he also said he was pretty sure it was a fibroadenoma. Long story short, my path came back as something rare so they sent it away for a 2nd opinion and I had the lump removed on Friday. Final path is a fibroadenoma. My lump was oval and moveable as well. It's very nerve wracking, but like Melissa said the odds are really in your favor. Fibroadenomas are pretty common from what I gather.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Tomorrow STP127 Jenny2578

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2013 02:55PM belha wrote: I am dealing with the same thing. Oval, well defined edges, moveable, etc. They think its a fibroadenoma as well, but sent me for a core needle biopsy because of its size. I am glad they did just for the peace of mind (still waiting on results tho) so at least we will know exactly what it is and if it turns out to be something more there was no wait around and see period of time. Just action! If I were you I'd want to do the biopsy.
